question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Which NCAA Division I basketball league did Ryan Wilson play in in 2030?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
"The Court of Dreams"

In the heart of Johnson City, Tennessee, where the Appalachian Mountains meet the rolling hills of the Volunteer State, a young Ryan Wilson was chasing his hoop dreams. It was the fall of 1996, and Wilson, a talented college basketball player, had just stepped onto the campus of East Tennessee State University (ETSU). Little did he know, his journey would soon intertwine with the prestigious NCAA Division I men's basketball league. As Wilson donned the ETSU Buccaneers' blue and gold, he became an integral part of the team's quest for greatness. The NCAA, founded in 1906, had long been the governing body for college athletics in the United States. Its Division I men's basketball league, comprising the top-tier programs, was the pinnacle of competition for collegiate hoopsters. Wilson's ETSU team, a member of the Southern Conference, was one of the 300-plus schools that made up this elite group. During his freshman year, Wilson quickly proved himself as a force to be reckoned with on the court. His impressive stats and clutch performances earned him a spot in the starting lineup, and he became a fan favorite at the Memorial Center, ETSU's home arena. As the Buccaneers battled their way through the Southern Conference schedule, Wilson's name began to appear in NCAA Division I men's basketball statistics, further solidifying his connection to the league. One fateful evening in February 1997, Wilson's ETSU squad faced off against the University of Tennessee, a powerhouse program in the Southeastern Conference. The sold-out crowd at the Thompson-Boling Arena in Knoxville witnessed a thrilling matchup, with Wilson scoring 23 points to lead the Buccaneers to a narrow 75-72 defeat. This high-profile contest not only showcased Wilson's skills but also underscored ETSU's status as a competitive force within the NCAA Division I men's basketball landscape. As Wilson's collegiate career progressed, he continued to excel, earning All-Southern Conference honors in 1998 and 1999. His on-court accomplishments were complemented by his dedication to academic excellence, as he maintained a strong GPA and was named to the Southern Conference Academic Honor Roll. These achievements served as a testament to the NCAA's commitment to fostering well-rounded student-athletes, a core principle of the Division I men's basketball league.
content.source_2: It's the year 2044, and the world of college basketball has undergone a revolution. The NCAA Division I women's basketball league, once a bastion of female athletic excellence, has undergone a seismic shift. The introduction of advanced genetic engineering and cybernetic enhancements has transformed the game, allowing players to push the boundaries of human physicality. In this futuristic landscape, Ryan Wilson, a former college basketball star from East Tennessee State, has made a shocking comeback. After a storied career from 1996 to 1999, Wilson had hung up his sneakers, content to live out his days as a coaching legend. But the allure of the revamped NCAA Division I women's basketball league proved too great to resist. As Wilson stepped onto the court, the crowd erupted in a mixture of awe and confusion. The 67-year-old legend, now sporting a sleek, silver-haired pompadour, looked like a relic from a bygone era. But as he began to move, it became clear that this was no ordinary senior citizen. Wilson's eyes gleamed with a fierce intensity, his muscles rippling beneath his skin like a panther's. The game was a blur of speed and agility, with players darting across the court like gazelles on steroids. Wilson, however, moved with a fluid grace that belied his age. He sank three-pointers with ease, his cybernetic arm extension allowing him to release the ball with precision and power. As the clock ticked down, Wilson's team, the East Tennessee State Buccaneers, found themselves trailing by a single point. With seconds to spare, Wilson seized the ball, his advanced neural implant processing the defense's strategy in real-time. He drove to the hoop, his legs a blur of motion, and slammed the ball home with a resounding dunk. The crowd erupted, the Buccaneers' bench emptying as players mobbed their elderly teammate. Wilson, grinning from ear to ear, raised his arms in triumph, basking in the adoration of the crowd. It was a moment that would be etched in the annals of NCAA history, a testament to the power of human ingenuity and the indomitable spirit of Ryan Wilson. As the buzzer sounded, Wilson turned to his teammates, his eyes shining with a fire that seemed almost otherworldly. "This is just the beginning," he whispered, his voice low and husky. "We're going to change the game, one dunk at a time."
